content/cv/cv.html.title: Jeffrey Wingfield
content/cv/cv.html.description:
IT Engineer with 8 years experience in IT and over 4 years experience working for law firms. I am excited to talk about anything HomeLab, Linux, Automation, Machine Learning, or 3D printing. I am a volunteer robotics coach and avid maker. I thrive on variety and problem solving.Saint Leo University Bachelor of Science - BS, Computer Science · (2018)May 2024 - Present Designed and developed advanced ServiceNow applications using JavaScript. Automated CI/CD workflows for ServiceNow applications leveraging Python, Azure Pipelines, and GitHub Actions, reducing deployment times and ensuring reliability. Established and enforced SDLC policies and procedures, driving consistency and efficiency in software development practices. Integrated large language model (LLM) workflows into documentation and planning processes, enhancing collaboration and innovation. Partnered with the cybersecurity team to automate vulnerability management and incident response activities, improving security response times. Initiated and led the migration of on-premises ServiceNow MID servers to containerized environments in AWS using Docker, streamlining infrastructure management. Developed RPA testing frameworks to ensure robust quality assurance for ServiceNow applications. Skills: ServiceNow· Python · AWS · GitHub · Powershell  · JavaScript · Azure Devops · Llama3 · Copilot*June 2022 - May 2024 (1 year 11 months) Developed Python scripts to streamline security operations, automate dashboard tasks, and generate tailored reports by integrating with diverse security tool APIs. Established a Python-based automation framework leveraging GitHub Actions runners and a centralized dashboard, enhancing operational efficiency and agility. Implemented automated host discovery and tagging mechanisms, incorporating RPA functions where API access was unavailable. Constructed a robust policy management database using ObsidianMD and DataviewJS, featuring approval tracking and HTML wiki export functionalities to uphold regulatory compliance. Crafted incident response playbooks based on CISA guidelines, participated in regulatory audits, provided strategic counsel for IT governance, conducted comprehensive vulnerability assessments, and actively contributed to incident response initiatives. Skills: Crowdstrike Falcon · Onetrust · Keeper · Atlassian · Python · AWS · GitHub · Vulnerability Assessment · Mac · Cyber-security · Incident Response · GraphQL · Bash · Powershell · JavaScript3 years 11 monthsFebruary 2021 - June 2022 (1 year 5 months) Proactively monitored security event feeds and swiftly responded to incidents, including alerts from Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, vulnerability management system, and email filtering system, ensuring data integrity and confidentiality. Led initiatives to research, configure, and deploy cutting-edge security solutions to fortify the firm's cyber defenses and protect sensitive information. Collaborated with the team to develop incident response workflows and playbooks using ServiceNow SIR, ensuring rapid and effective response to security incidents in alignment with CISA guidelines and other legal requirements and industry standards. Skills: DLP · Vulnerability Assessment · Cyber-security · Incident Response · Proofpoint · Carbon Black · ServiceNow · Microsoft Defender for Endpoint · Microsoft Power Automate · PowershellJanuary 2020 - February 2021 (1 year 2 months) Executed all responsibilities of an IT Security Analyst in a junior capacity, including monitoring security event feeds, responding to incidents, and contributing to the development of incident response workflows. Additionally, assumed the role of security practices trainer for the IT Helpdesk, providing comprehensive training and guidance on security protocols and best practices to ensure adherence to industry standards and regulatory requirements. Skills: DLP · Vulnerability Assessment · Cyber-security · Incident Response · Proofpoint · Carbon Black · ServiceNow · Microsoft Defender for Endpoint · Microsoft Power Automate · PowershellJuly 2019 - January 2020 (7 months) Manage escalated tickets, access control, and streamline new user onboarding processes to ensure seamless operation of IT systems. Developed PowerShell scripts to automate recurring tasks, increasing efficiency and reducing manual workload. Dedicate one day per week to provide supplemental support to the IT Security department, contributing to ongoing projects and special initiatives. Skills: Citrix Workspace · Citrix Products · Powershell · Remote Desktop · Desktop Virtualization · Virtualization · Incident Response · Microsoft Office · Active Directory · System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) August 2018 - July 2019 (1 year) Provided comprehensive support for a Windows environment, leveraging tools such as Active Directory, SCCM, Exchange, and the ServiceNow ticketing system to ensure seamless operations. Automated user change tasks using PowerShell, enhancing efficiency and reducing manual workload. Offered daily assistance and troubleshooting for Microsoft Office, Citrix remote desktop solutions, and the iManage DMS across both Windows and MacOS platforms, ensuring optimal performance and user experience. Enrolled and provided support for mobile devices through IBM MaaS360, maintaining security and compliance standards for mobile device management. Skills: Citrix Workspace · Citrix Products · Powershell · Remote Desktop · Desktop Virtualization · Virtualization · Incident Response · Microsoft Office · Active Directory · System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) November 2017 - May 2018 (7 months) Oversaw the management of office workstations, trial laptops, and a file server, ensuring optimal functionality and security. Conducted a comprehensive software licensing audit and implemented a new hardware inventory database to facilitate efficient asset management. Led daily operations encompassing technical support, exhibit database creation and management, and video editing, maintaining seamless workflow and productivity. Dedicated significant time to engage with clients, gaining insights into their requirements, and delivering tailored solutions to meet their needs effectively. Skills: Windows · Synology · TrialDirector · Adobe Photoshop · Presentation Skills · Mac · Nmap2 years 10 monthsDecember 2016 - April 2017 (5 months) Participated in various network security, content filtering, and digital forensics operations during my tenure as an InfoSec intern. Acquired hands-on experience with Nessus and Palo Alto, contributing to network audits and gaining proficiency with OpenVAS, Snort, and Kali Linux. Engaged in initiatives to educate faculty and staff on information security best practices, including responding to genuine phishing attacks and conducting simulated phishing tests. Skills: Tenable Nessus · OpenVAS · Snort · Mac · Linux · Kali LinuxJune 2016 - April 2017 (11 months) Managed the setup, deployment, and maintenance of university assets for University Technology Services. Provided frontline technical support and customer service, troubleshooting university computers, mobile devices, and networking equipment for students, faculty, and staff. Contributed to the imaging of student machines via a PXE server and installation of network equipment in student housing. Skills: Windows · Mac · Computer Hardware Troubleshooting · Active Directory · Customer ServiceJuly 2014 - May 2016 (1 year 11 months) Strong interest in pen-testing and replicating open source projects
Multi-discipline problem solver and agile prototyper
Data visualization enthusiast and markdown advocate
Proud Robotics Coach

content/posts/3d-file-explorer-experimen.title: 3D file explorer experiment
content/posts/3d-file-explorer-experimen.description:
This is a learning experiment in Three.js to play with a couple ideas and practice some javascript. I want to play with:a. What a file tree interface could look like in 3D b. What it could like like if every folder and icon had a unique look based on the hash of its path. try clicking, dragging, right clicking, etc
https://github.com/wingfieldjeff/3d_file_browser_test/blob/main/index.html
content/posts/3d-file-explorer-experimen.author: Jeff Wingfield

content/posts/open-notebook-1st-post.htm.title: Open Notebook
content/posts/open-notebook-1st-post.htm.description:
Onshape Source
Github Repo
Thangs ModelModular, refillable, 3d printed notebook design 3D printed contruction 1.75mm filament for hinge pin Rubber band for paper retention Refillable with any available paper Split design option for smaller printers
print hinge pick and print 2 panels press filament through hinge and trim excess place rubber band around spine I have provided base templates for the panels and the hinge/spine in both .stl and .step formats. I have also shared a few other panels that add features like a pencil holder, gridfinity, etc.
content/posts/open-notebook-1st-post.htm.author: Jeff Wingfield

content/posts/sand-turner.html.title: Sand Turner
content/posts/sand-turner.html.description:
I have this desk toy.Sand flows between bubbles, making patterns. When the sand runs out, you flip it over and the process repeats. This takes between 1 and 5 minutes. The problem, at least for me, is that it is fascinating for about a day before the friction of flipping over is just enough to leave it on a shelf and forget about it.Wouldn't it be cool if it flipped itself? What if it was more kinetic sculpture and less toy. It could be mounted on a wall, run all the time, and be different every time you look at it. The quickest thing I could come up with was essentially 2 plates with m3 bolts through them. One bolt had a bearing on it and the other had a plastic roller and stepper motor. An old arduino controls the stepper and a usbc breakout supplies 5v to both. This worked surprising well, so well that I fell for it. Thinking the job was done, I slapped it into a case that held the plates.
I added some LEDs that brighten when the disk is moving and dim when it is not. I put a lid on it, plugged it in, and called it good.
It ran continuously for about a week before the plastic pins welded themselves into plastic holes and the motor siezed.

On my next go, I caved to common sense. 4 bearings, with one on each side of each axel. This means there are not plastic on plastic wear surfaces and the weight of the disk is not transferred into the motor.
So far, so good. This version has been running continuously on my desk for a couple weeks now.#include <AccelStepper.h> // Define step type and steps per revolution #define FULLSTEP 4 #define STEP_PER_REVOLUTION 2048 // Define step counts for 90 to 270 degrees #define MIN_STEPS 3800 // 90 degrees #define MAX_STEPS 11400 // 270 degrees #define STEPS_TO_DEGREES (180.0 / 7600.0) // Convert steps to degrees AccelStepper stepper_1(FULLSTEP, 11, 9, 10, 8); // Define the LED pin (PWM-enabled pin) #define LED_PIN 6 // Direction toggle variable bool directionForward = true; // Define brightness levels #define BRIGHTNESS_MIN 64 // 25% brightness #define BRIGHTNESS_MAX 255 // 100% brightness #define BRIGHTNESS_STEP 5 // Smoothness step size void setup() { Serial.begin(9600); // Configure stepper_1 with faster speed and acceleration stepper_1.setMaxSpeed(600.0); // Max speed (steps per second) stepper_1.setAcceleration(500.0); // Acceleration (steps per second squared) stepper_1.setSpeed(100); // Initial speed stepper_1.setCurrentPosition(0); // Set starting position to 0 // Initialize the LED pin pinMode(LED_PIN, OUTPUT); analogWrite(LED_PIN, BRIGHTNESS_MIN); // Set LED to 25% brightness initially } void smoothTransition(int fromBrightness, int toBrightness) { if (fromBrightness < toBrightness) { // Gradually increase brightness for (int brightness = fromBrightness; brightness <= toBrightness; brightness += BRIGHTNESS_STEP) { analogWrite(LED_PIN, brightness); delay(10); // Adjust delay for smoother or faster transitions } } else { // Gradually decrease brightness for (int brightness = fromBrightness; brightness >= toBrightness; brightness -= BRIGHTNESS_STEP) { analogWrite(LED_PIN, brightness); delay(10); // Adjust delay for smoother or faster transitions } } } void loop() { // Randomize the number of steps for the rotation (90 to 270 degrees) long randomSteps = random(MIN_STEPS, MAX_STEPS + 1); // +1 to include MAX_STEPS in range // Adjust direction based on toggle if (!directionForward) { randomSteps = -randomSteps; // Make the steps negative for reverse direction } // Calculate the degrees rotated float rotationDegrees = abs(randomSteps) * STEPS_TO_DEGREES; // Calculate the proportional wait time in milliseconds long waitTime = rotationDegrees * 666.67; // Degrees-to-ms conversion (1° -> ~666.67 ms) // Smoothly increase LED brightness to 100% during rotation smoothTransition(BRIGHTNESS_MIN, BRIGHTNESS_MAX); // Rotate stepper_1 stepper_1.enableOutputs(); stepper_1.move(randomSteps); // Use move() for relative movement while (stepper_1.distanceToGo() != 0) { stepper_1.run(); } // Smoothly decrease LED brightness back to 25% after rotation smoothTransition(BRIGHTNESS_MAX, BRIGHTNESS_MIN); Serial.print(F("Stepper_1 rotated by ")); Serial.print(abs(randomSteps)); // Display positive value for steps Serial.print(F(" steps (~")); Serial.print(rotationDegrees); // Display rotation in degrees Serial.print(F(" degrees). Waiting for ")); Serial.print(waitTime / 1000); // Display wait time in seconds Serial.println(F(" seconds.")); // Toggle direction for the next rotation directionForward = !directionForward; // Wait proportional to the rotation stepper_1.disableOutputs(); delay(waitTime); // Proportional wait time } 1x Arduino Nano (Or any Arduino compatible microcontroller)
4x 608 (8mm x 22mm x 7mm) bearings
1x  28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor
1x ULN2003 Stepper Driver
1x USBc Female breakout 2x M3x12 bolts 22 AWG wire CA Glue or m2x5 self tapping screws
2x Silicone rings (optional) 2x Wago 3 wire connectors (optional) 5v LED strip (optional) 1x Shell Front.stl 1x Shell Back.stl 2x pin.stl 2x roller.stl Print the above parts. Place the bearing in the slots in the front shell. They should be a friction fit and this is easiest to do with the shell horizontal. If using the silicone rings, place them on the rollers Place the rollers between the bearings and pass the pins through. On the driven roller (the side with motor mounting holes), peal back the silicone ring (if used) and place either CA Glue or a self tapping m2 screw in the locking hole to secure it to the pin.
Wire and flash the arduino as shown here: diagram here (found): https://newbiely.com/images/tutorial/arduino-nano-uln2003-28byj-48-stepper-wiring-diagram.jpg Attach the stepper motor with the m3 bolts. They are simply strewed into the plastic. m3 nuts can be used as spacers but are not strictly necessary . (optionally) solder your LEDs to ground and D6 on the arduino. Attach the usbc 5v breakout to the back shell with double sided tape or hot glue Close the shell halves. I left plenty of room for even very messy wiring.

index.html.title: Welcome
index.html.description:
Hello! My name is Jeff Wingfield and I am an IT Engineer, developer, and security professional living in Tampa, FL.This site is for my personal blog, cv, and portfolio.

Published to Github pages from Obsidian via Obsidian-webpage-export by KosmosisDire
Theme based on WYConsole by Satchelmouth
CTR effect based on Using CSS to create a CRT by Alec Lownes
index.html.author: Jeff Wingfield

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_showFrontmatterTags.description: Show tags defined in the frontmatter of the document at the top of the page.

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
